abstract: A brisk but dazzling 500-year shoe survey, booting the idea that foot fashion needs to be grounded.
snippet: A brisk but dazzling 500-year shoe survey, booting the idea that foot fashion needs to be grounded.
lead_paragraph: "100 Shoes" (The Metropolitan Museum of Art/Yale, $25) is not a collection of fashion's most vertically daring heels, despite the Vivienne Westood platforms on the cover (and a preface by that stilt walker Sarah Jessica Parker). Instead it's a brisk but dazzling 500-year shoe survey, booting the idea that foot fashion needs to be grounded: Moccasins were huge in Georgian England; American tango boots in the 1910s laced up like Grecian sandals; and that late-'60s prototype by Beth Levine - it kicks off the shoe slideshow above - seems to have come from a different planet.
